lines.text:
[Smoking a cigarette, staring at Georgine's behind as she is bent over on top of a ladder looking for a hammer]
I guess you ain't got - just what I want.
No one has anything to do with my future, but, myself. As long as I have just myself to look after, I'll do all right.
All right, girls, line up!

Now, snap into it girls!. And go to your departments as I call your assignments. Clerks 1203, 4, 5, 6 and 7, 1806, 2210 - millinery. 1161, 3, 5 and 6, 1402 and 3 - the stock room. All right, come girls, snap into it, snap into it! 1404 - infant's wear. 1492 and 3 - lace. 1123, 4, 5 and 6 - gloves.
Looks like I'll never get away from plumbing. Working there by day and scrubbing here at night. My life goes by in bathrooms.
Say, you oughta grab off a swell guy like Elmer and stop being so moony! He's daffy about you.
The only thing I wanta grab off is a load of sleep. I'm dead!
Stop reading these screwy books!
Why, I wanta get someplace. I want to be somebody.
You don't see Peggy Joyce reading no merchandising books and she's somebody. Her merchandise is the the kind that sells on sight.

[Wind blows away a pair of panties hang drying in the window]
Oh! Oh! Oh-oh-oh!
What's the matter?
Oh, there goes my last panties!
Well, now what are you gonna do?
Keep off of step ladders.
So you're Buster, huh? And you belong to Elmer? Oh, say it ain't so, baby, Say it ain't so!
It ain't, mister. It ain't.
Are you a doctor?
Oh, a heart specialist. Let me feel your pulse. Oh, it's too slow - for love at first sight!
[Buster laughs]
Oh, no love at first sight?
No.
Well, second sight? Don't you believe in love at all?
[Buster shrugs her shoulders]
You must be married.
Okay, baby, you and me!
Say, you're pretty sure of yourself, aren't ya?
I wish I was half as sure of you - but, I will be! The next time we meet.
I don't think I like you. You're much too fresh!
Don't let that bother ya. I think you're swell.
Elmer and Georgine are probably waiting. We better go.
Lady, you've got an awful lot to learn; but, I'll fix that. You know, this world is just full of little girls that I helped educate.
Sorry, Professor; but, I graduated a long time ago.
Well, honey, there's nothing like a post-graduate course.
I'll let you know all about that at lunch.
Oh, yes?
Well, perhaps, not all. I better save a few of the details for dinner.
And what about breakfast?
Well, I'm easily persuaded.
Give us a kiss.
With pleasure.
[Gives Wally a short peck on his lips]
That's a mighty poor brand for this day and age.
Well, what kind would you like sir?
Oh, send over some samples. What kind have you got?
Well, I have animal, mineral and vegetable.
Oh? Animal!

[Gives Buster a kiss]
How was that?
Oh, no technique! Why, they can do better than that in the movies. Come on, Gable, get hot!
Are you going?
Yeah, I hate to; but, I got to see this bird on business. Hey, here's some dough. Do some shopping, will ya?
Say, how much money you got?
Oh, I've got plenty, darling.
Yeah, well, how much?
Oh, seventy dollars, or so.
Wally, haven't you got a job at all?
No. I lied to you, honey. I make my money gambling.
Oh.
Are you mad?
Hail, the bride! Married three months and still smiling!
Can I see the bedroom?
Of course, you can.
You usually do.
Yeah? Well, you oughta know. I generally meet you - coming out!
Hey, don't you know its bad luck to put a hat on a bed.

[to Buster]
New clothes, too! Say, I'd take the fatal leap, myself, if I could land into a closet full of clothes like that. Say, this is a lot different from the old days, when we only had one pair of panties a piece.
Bragging again.
Say, why don't you two get married? He knows all the answers.
Aw, go pump up your bicycle!
I went to a doctor today.
A doctor? What for?
What do you suppose?
Oh, Bus! Oh, that's swell! Oh boy, I'm happy. Say, what a thrill.
Still tied up with apron strings, eh?
What a joke you'll be on your husband - if you ever hook some poor sap!
Listen, dearie, I'm all right and I don't want any husband!
Oh, no, you don't want a husband. No. Not much! You just go around smiling at lamp posts and fireplugs!
Say, he don't know a good thing when he's got it. Where is the mug? I'd like to give him a good sock on his button.
Georgine, you're not going to get married?
Eh-heh. Oh, Bus, I know it don't sound so good to you. But, I'm gettin' kinda old and I got to find out what its all about before its too late.
Well, I'm happy for your sake, hon.
You know, the company's giving Finky a route and gonna send him out on the road for our honeymoon. He's going to demonstrate folding beds.
Wanna cup of coffee, sister?
How much is this?
Soup and sandwich. Fifteen cents.
That's all. Thank you.
Say, Mrs. Dennis, what horse have you got?
I got two dollars on Baby Mine.
Baby Mine? To win?
Yes. Its got a chance, hasn't it?
Well, the odds are 30 to 1 that it won't win. Who touted it to you?
Nobody. I just have a hunch.
The streets are crowded with people that play hunches.
Well, well, fancy seeing you here. How was the honeymoon?
Why don't you get married and find out.
I suppose you're looking for your girlfriend Buster.
I am! What department is she in now?
She must be selling apples. They threw her out over a month ago.
What?
Sure. I heard after her husband gave her the gate, she went on the make for every man in the place.
Oh yeah.
I always thought she was a play girl. *If* you know what I mean?
Why, you, mother - I ought to let you have it!
When are you going to the hospital kid?
Any day now.
Which one?
County, I guess. That's what it cost to go to a good one.
Holy mackerel! Three-hundred and five dollars for one baby! You sure that ain't for twins?

[Buster and Georgine kiss on the lips after Georgine gives her $50 to help her out]
Bye. Oh, gee, you're swell! I hope the kid is half as swell as you are.
Oh, forget it. If he's anything like me, I'll spank the pants off of him - or her.
It's a dame's money. You don't think I'd be sucker enough to bet on a goat like that, do you?
Hey, your dame wasn't so dumb after all, was she?
Aw, just lucky. Well, all my dames are that way.
I got to see her! I got to talk to her!

I'm tellin' ya she'll be all right. I've had six kids myself and my wife came through all right. It's tough on us men, waitin' out here, that's all! Ah, brace up. Be a man! Take hold of yourself. Now, ain't I tellin' ya there's nothin' to worry about.
